clean_story:
"Faint glows. Billions of miles away. "

"Exoplanets" are planets outside our solar system—so far that even their host stars look like tiny dots.

Studying them is like guessing the shape of a firefly next to a searchlight… from another continent.
Most exoplanets don’t emit light—they’re spotted when they pass in front of their star, dimming it slightly.
A 1% dip in brightness might mean a Jupiter-sized planet.
A 0. 01% dip? Maybe an Earth-sized one.
But stars flicker naturally, mimicking false signals.
Even the James Webb Telescope, our sharpest eye, struggles to analyze their atmospheres—like sniffing a single perfume molecule in a hurricane.
Take TRAPPIST-1e, 40 light-years away.
We know it’s rocky and in the "habitable zone," but its air? Maybe oxygen, maybe toxic haze.
Distance turns data into educated guesses.
Light from Proxima Centauri b, our nearest exoplanet, takes 4. 2 years to reach us.
By the time we see it, the planet’s weather could’ve changed entirely.
Then there’s noise: cosmic rays, instrument glitches, even Earth’s atmosphere blurring space telescopes.
Finding a second Earth isn’t just hard—it’s a game of patience, luck, and waiting for technology to catch up.

Light pollution from cities…
The limits of spectroscopy…
How gravity lenses could one day sharpen our view.
